questions.question_text: Complete the sentence. TOGAF 9 Part III provides techniques, such as developing principles and gap analysis, to support tasks within the ______

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
17.2 Techniques for Architecture Development
• Architecture Principles 
• Stakeholder Management 
• Architecture Patterns 
• Gap Analysis 
• Migration Planning Techniques 
• Requirements
• Business Transformation Readiness Assessment 
• Risk Management 
• Capability-Based Planning 

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap17.html

Correct Answer 

Reference
17.2 Techniques for Architecture Development

Note for consideration, the question specifies "Scope". 
The scope aspect of depth = "enterprise coverage" while the characteristic aspect of depth = "subject matter".

Scope:
- Breadth
- Depth
- Time Period
- Architecture Domains

Characteristics:
- Breadth
- Depth
- Time
- Recency

Selected Answer: D
4.5 Scoping the Architecture
4.5.1 Breadth
One of the key decisions is the focus of the architecture effort
4.5.2 Depth
Care should be taken to judge the appropriate level of detail to be captured
4.5.3 Time Period
4.5.4 Architecture Domains


https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/m/chap04.html

Correct Answer 
4.5 Scoping the Architecture
Four dimensions are typically used in order to define and limit the scope of an architecture:

Breadth
Depth
Time Period
Architecture Domains

comments.content: The four dimensions of architecture scope are explored in detail below. In each case, particularly in largescale environments where architectures are necessarily developed in a federated manner, there is a danger of architects optimizing within their own scope of activity, instead of at the level of the overall enterprise. It is often necessary to sub-optimize in a particular area, in order to optimize at the enterprise level. The aim should always be to seek the highest level of commonality and focus on scalable and re-usable modules in order to maximize re-use at the enterprise level.

questions.question_text: According to TOGAF, the recommended dimensions used to define the scope of an architecture include all the following, except:
In the Solutions Continuum, which of the following is the correct order of Solutions from most-specific to most-generic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
39.4.2 Solutions Continuum
1-Foundation Solutions
Foundation Solutions are highly generic concepts
2-Common Systems Solutions
3-Industry Solutions
4-Organization-Specific Solutions
An Organization-Specific Solution is an implementation of the Organization-Specific Architecture 

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap39.html

Selected Answer: E
27.2 Suggested Steps
Where an ABB from the Baseline Architecture is missing in the Target Architecture, each must be reviewed. If it was correctly eliminated, mark it as such in the appropriate "Eliminated" cell. If it was not, an accidental omission in the Target Architecture has been uncovered that must be addressed by reinstating the ABB in the next iteration of the architecture design - mark it as such in the appropriate "Eliminated" cell.
Where an ABB from the Target Architecture cannot be found in the Baseline Architecture, mark it at the intersection with the "New" row as a gap that needs to filled, either by developing or procuring the building block.
When the exercise is complete, anything under "Eliminated" or "New" is a gap, which should either be explained as correctly eliminated, or marked as to be addressed by reinstating or developing/procuring the function.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/m/chap27.html

Correct Answer 

23.2 Suggested Steps
Where an ABB from the Target Architecture cannot be found in the Baseline Architecture, mark it at the intersection with the "New" row as a gap that needs to filled, either by developing or procuring the building block
When the exercise is complete, anything under "Eliminated" or "New" is a gap, which should either be explained as correctly eliminated, or marked as to be addressed by reinstating or developing/procuring the function.

choices.E: a new function that must be built or procured
choices.B: an error has occurred and the architecture must be re-evaluated
choices.C: requirements have not been properly documented

questions.question_text:
Complete the sentence. In a gap analysis, a building block that appears in the Target Architecture but does not appear in the Baseline Architecture indicates
_____
According to TOGAF, which of the following is the usual approach for developing the Baseline Business Architecture if no architecture or few architecture assets exist?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Approach
Developing the Baseline Description
The normal approach to Target Architecture development is top-down. In the Baseline Description, however, the analysis of the current state often has to be done bottom-up

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf8-doc/arch/chap06.html

Selected Answer: A
A. Bottom up

8.2.2 Developing the Baseline Description "The normal approach to Target Architecture development is top-down. In the Baseline Description, however, the analysis of the current state often has to be done bottom-up, particularly where little or no architecture assets exist"
